headline.main: IMPORTANT FROM EUROPE.; The French Scheme for a Ship Canal in Nicaragua. Decline in Cotton---Consols Unchanged. Successful Trial Trip of the Atlantic Telegraph Steamers. Explanation of M. Belly's Mission. Lord Brougham on the SlaveTrade. Arrival of the Arago at this Port and the Europa at Halifax. THE BRITISH AGGRESSIONS BEFORE PARLIAMENT. OPINIONS OF THE ENGLISH PRESS. OVERHAULING AMERICAN SHIPS DISAVOWED.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Steamship Arogo, from Southampton on the 2d of June, arrived at this port yesterday morning. The R. M. steamship Europa, Capt. LEITCH, from Liverpool at 10 o'clock on the afternoon of the 5th inst., arrived at Halifax at 12 1/2 o'clock, yesterday afternoon, bringing three days later news than the Arags.

docs.snippet: The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A communication was received from James W. Wallack, in consequence of his having been assessed as worth $20,000. He states that he is not worth anything over and above what would...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met last evening, President CLANCY in the Chair. A communication was received from James W. Wallack, in consequence of his having been assessed as worth $20,000. He states that he is not worth anything over and above what would meet his indebtedness.

headline.main: LATEST BY TELEGRAPH.; The St. Joseph and Placerville Mall Route-Heavy Fall Importations Expected Summer Exodus, &c. The Special Session of the Senate. INTERESTING FROM WASHINGTON, General Johnston's Utah Dispatches Laid Before the Cabinet.

docs.lead_paragraph: The War Department laid Gen. JOHNSTON'S dis-. patches before the Cabinet to-day. The President is much perplexed by the contradiction these dispatches give to those received from Gov. CUMMING, and expresses his regret at what he now considers his premaure message to Congress, announcing the end of the Mormon Rebellion.

docs.snippet: THE AFFAIR AT THE NEW-YORK HOTEL.--NO arrests have yet been made in the matter of the assault at the New-York Hotel on Monday night, when a distinguished literary character was severely beaten by a distinguished fillibuster. The disturbance grew out...
docs.lead_paragraph: THE AFFAIR AT THE NEW-YORK HOTEL.--NO arrests have yet been made in the matter of the assault at the New-York Hotel on Monday night, when a distinguished literary character was severely beaten by a distinguished fillibuster. The disturbance grew out of what was deemed an unwarrantable interference on the part of the literary gentleman with the exhibition of some tricks with cards by a third party.

docs.snippet: Trial of Patrick Lally for the Murder of George H. Simonson. SECOND DAY. KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER--JUNE 15. Before Hon. Selah B. Strong, Judge, and Justices Schoonmaker and Kultmons. TESTIMONY OF THE PROSECUTION CONTINUED. Dr. Daniel...
docs.lead_paragraph: Trial of Patrick Lally for the Murder of George H. Simonson. SECOND DAY. KINGS COUNTY COURT OF OYER AND TERMINER--JUNE 15. Before Hon. Selah B. Strong, Judge, and Justices Schoonmaker and Kultmons. TESTIMONY OF THE PROSECUTION CONTINUED. Dr. Daniel Ayres, recalled--The wound on the face gives no indication as to the blow, except that it was probably struck obliquely from the front -- a little to the left of the person struck.

headline.main: THE BRITISH AGGRESSIONS.; IMPORTANT FROM BERMUDA. The Causes of Complaint in the Gulf to be Stopped. Nature of the Dispatches from the British Admiral. Interview Between Lord Napier :and Secretary Cass. Important Debate in the United States Senate. Consideration of the Resolutions of the Commitee on Foreign Relations.

docs.abstract: Interview between Lord Napier and Genl Cass
docs.lead_paragraph: The Debate in the Senate Yesterday. Mr. MASON called up the resolutions heretofore reported from the Committee on Foreign Relations, in regard to the question of British aggressions. It seemed to him a matter of moment that the judgment of the Senate should be passed upon them, because of the probable beating they may have on any negotiation now pending.

docs.snippet: At Walworth, N. Y., last week, Mrs. GANNETT drank strychnine. Cause--aberration, resulting from ill health. At Bullville, Orange County, N.Y., a few days ago, a young lady named Nuck took arsenic. Cause--desertion by her lover.
docs.lead_paragraph: At Walworth, N. Y., last week, Mrs. GANNETT drank strychnine. Cause--aberration, resulting from ill health. At Bullville, Orange County, N.Y., a few days ago, a young lady named Nuck took arsenic. Cause--desertion by her lover.

docs.snippet: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Among the numerous laws by which we are, or ought to be governed, there are some good, some defective, some paltry, some ridiculous; but whatever the intrinsic merit of the law, it is right that is appointed...

headline.main: Our City Misgovernment--A Great Pass over Small Matters and Neglect of Large Ones.

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor of the New-York Times: Among the numerous laws by which we are, or ought to be governed, there are some good, some defective, some paltry, some ridiculous; but whatever the intrinsic merit of the law, it is right that is appointed guardians should see to its being obeyed.

docs.snippet: SUMMER RESORTS.-The hotels at the various watering places are making arrangements for the coming season. Mr. WEAVER, of the Occan House at Newport, is making great changes and repairs in his establishment, which has become one of the indispensable...
docs.lead_paragraph: SUMMER RESORTS.-The hotels at the various watering places are making arrangements for the coming season. Mr. WEAVER, of the Occan House at Newport, is making great changes and repairs in his establishment, which has become one of the indispensable institutions of that most charming place.
